content.description: A fairly consistent route climbing the slightly overhung corner.  Takes great gear and there are plenty of features on the right and left wall to stem.
content.protection: Nuts and small cams.  A new anchor was installed in 2013.  Clip chains at the top to the right of the corner, no need to scramble up the scary perched blocks at the top anymore!
content.location: The obvious dihedral corner on the Southeast side of the Single Malt Wall.  The base of this route has an intimidating granite slope.  A single chain has been installed to prevent climber or belayer from tumbling before any gear has been placed.

content.description: Climb up onto the shelf then up to the arete. Ease your way up and under the first roof, pull that and find a good no hands rest.  The second roof is much harder and deposits you at a final juggy edge with 6 feet of blankness to reach the ledge.  Go ahead and launch! Jump your ass off!  Theres a bolt to protect you and help you cheat past this giant move if you can't quite stick it or need to suss things out.  Traverse left to reach the sport anchor at the lip.  This climb is so fun, a rock star for sure!!  Try it if you like to dyno.  The grade may or may not fit you, or be totally irrelevant, just do it!
content.location: Between LaPhroaig and Oban

content.description: Step up on the boulder adjacent to the wall and clip the first bolt. Step right and onto the wall and its on!  Short, powerful and just steep enough to get you pumped! You are climbing opposing side pulls of varying sizes from open hand slopers to tiny crimps.  There are just enough jugs thrown in to offer clipping stances and occasional rests.
content.location: Just left of A Hint of Ollorosso.

content.description:
This route is deceptively steep with sustained difficulties all the way to the end.  Short though pretty stout!  The crux is probably negotiating the ledge at bolt 3 and then dealing with the short hand crack above that.

Snowflake is the once a year second casking product Stranahans distillery offers.  One barrel, one day to buy it, show up early on site to get one.  Very exclusive, each year it is a bit different.  Man I'd love to get my hands on a bottle.  Any Denverites wanna stand in line for me?
content.protection: 6 clips, sport anchor also chains at the base for belaying and lowering back to the ground.
content.location: This is a second pitch route.  Access it by climbing La Phroaig, Stranahans, Oban or Glen Morangie.  All these climbs lead to a large slanted ledge with a set of chains on the back wall, at the beginning of this climb.

content.description:
Starts basically on the road.  Climb easy terrain past 3 bolts to reach a dihedral and a roof with an obvious undercling.  Negotiate this little test and scamper up the dihedral to the steeper upper  headwall.  A tricky mantle guards the chains, watch your feet!

Not a Scotch, but a savory Single Malt Whiskey distilled right here in Cody with locally grown grains!  Delicious!
content.location: Located in the center of the Single Malt Wall just left of LaPhroaig.

content.description: This route is basically three boulder problems separated by good rests.  The last one is the business with a few smaller holds and steep climbing.
content.location: Just left of the obvious lieback corner climb Glen Morangie.  Stem the corner as if you were starting GM but move left immediately.  See topo photo under Single Malt Wall header.

content.description: You may want to stick clip the first bolt as this route has a boulder problem requiring a committing move to reach a jug next to the bolt.  Bend over here it comes again and again and again.  Always hard with no real rests and very few real holds, this route will test everything you know about rock climbing.  Underclings, pinches, slopers, kneebars, shoulder scums, meathooks - you name it, this route asks you to do it.  Figuring it out and sewing it together is a very rewarding process.  Good on ya to anyone that can onsight this route.
content.location: Just right of the alcove, this route tackles the obvious black and white streaked water scoop.

content.description: Scramble up easy ground past two bolts to reach a ledge and the third bolt.  Make a few moves up the arete to the right then trend back left to clip the fourth bolt.  Continue up to reach the left facing flake system.  This is steep and pumpy but is over with relatively quickly.  Mantle the ledge to reach the chains.  One of the best and most popular routes on the wall.
content.location: Right in the center of the wall beginning from the road.  Two low bolts protect the rambly mantles to reach a ledge and the first test.

content.description: This route wanders quite a bit, begin with the rounded crack of The Cragganmore but jog left 15 feet to reach the rest of the route.
content.location:
Traverse left from Turbocharger across the slanted slab to reach a belay bolt.  Start same as Cragganmore but when you reach the shelf, walk left about 15 feet to reach another crack system.

Its probably better to bring your belayer up to the ledge.  Walk left 15 feet over to the bolt and belay there.  4 bolts to the chains from there.

content.description: The first climbing bolt is near two large old lag bolts which are NOT used for this climb.  Clip bolts on the right as you wander up the corner.  The crux comes as you transition into the layback holds.  Cruise up with your feet on the slab and hands pulling on jugs to a mantle and the chains.  This can be the first pitch of two separate finishes, The Ardbeg 5.10c or The Angels Share 5.12d.  Bring your second up to the chains or continue on for one 100' long pitch.
content.location: The corner system in the back of the alcove

content.description: Climbs good edges up the pretty red and brown patinaed granite face.
content.location: The right most of the three routes on the East face

content.description:
A fun romp up the East face!  Follow mostly large holds with a few tricks along the way.  This route wanders a bit to stay on the biggest holds and sometimes away from the bolt line.  A little sharp and still a bit dirty, hopefully this line sees more traffic and cleans up a bit because its really quite good.

Originally given mid 5.11, if you follow the best holds it feels more like 5.10+.
content.location: Begins just right of The Chillarete.  It is the left most of the three routes on the East face.

content.description: A very technical route with good edges on very good brown and red patinaed granite.  Short but full value.
content.location: The Middle of the three routes on the East face.

climbs.name: Cragganmore
climbs.fa: Bolted by Winter Ramos, 2014, FA Mike Snyder 2015

content.description: Work your way up the rounded crack to the shelf above and continue up small features on the slightly overhung wall.
content.location: This route begins left of Turbocharger and the Chillarete on the slanted slab.  The belay stance has a bolt for the belayer so you don't tumble down to the road.

content.description: Work up the stepped arete to find a challenging crux that involves slapping slopers you wish were better.  Mantle and cruise up the last slabby section to a second top out.
content.location: The far right arete on plug of granite known as the Single Malt Wall.  Shares anchors with the trad line Turbocharger which is the corner to its left.  Scramble up the hillside and up the steep smooth slab to the base of the route.  A chain has been installed for the belayer so as not to tumble.

content.description: Move up and into a crack system.  The lower crux comes at the third clip revolving around a fist jam, crimps and a flaring crack.  Above, find horns and cool features in the wide jumbled gap, the bolts are easy to clip on the smooth face to the right.  As the gap trends left wander right and across the face to a small roof.  The second crux involves surmounting the roof, though you may fall navigating the smoother streaked rock above.  This is a great long slabby pitch with multiple styles and tricks required for success.
content.location: On the right side of the alcove.  Begin right above some scratched in grafitti from the 1920's

content.description: Another 100' long pitch linking the fun crack climbing at the bottom of Bowmore and the nearly all of the Ardbeg as the finish.
content.location: A link up beginning on The Bowmore and finishing up the Ardbeg

content.description: Climb up the angular road cut granite to reach the chimney. Wriggle up this funky feature until it peters out and forces you out onto the shallow dihedral. Weird jams, slopers, hidden holds and little crimps will guide you to an off-balance stance to clip the anchor. Sadly, this climb is no where near as good as the single malt of the same name, particularly the Doublewood.
content.location: Left of LaPhroaig and right of Auchentoshen. Look for the right facing chimney about 20' up.

content.description:
A slab characterized by great brownish colored granite for the first 25 feet, the rock then changes to a grayish color speckled with green lichen.  The climbable features diminish and the route gets cruxy.  Pull a steeper feature and mantle a ledge to find the chains.

Was given 5.11b but subsequent ascents have pushed up closer to 5.12a.
content.location: The left side of the wall.  Starts from the road and is marked by 3" wide drilled hole (another relic from this 90 year old roadway), which you can actually use as a starting foot hold.

content.description: From the chains of Glen Morangie step right and clip a bolt before launching up (skipping the last bolt of Glen Morangie and the chains reduces rope drag when doing the whole route as a long pitch).  Wander up through the small roof section on good holds.  Continue on cool slopers and trend left to a jug that is quite a stretch, clip and traverse back right thru the crux to get to the chains.
content.location: This is a second pitch to Glen Morangie but can be done as one 100' pitch.  Climb the Glen Morangie corner system to the chains.  The route trends right and up a small roof then up slabby terrain on perfect stone.

content.description: From the chains of Glen Morangie traverse left  back into the corner to begin.  Work up the corner then right and out onto the face (unclip the first two as you climb higher to reduce rope drag if you are linking the first and second pitch).  The climbing gets more difficult as you approach the roof.  A vicious boulder problem guards the first moves starting out the roof and two dynos are required to attain the lip.
content.location: This is a second pitch above Glen Morangie or you can string them all together for one 100' long pitch

content.description: climb up a slanting dihedral and surmount a bell shaped lip.  See any holds? I didn't either for a long time.  I enlisted the help of a friend and we found a solution.  Get to the the protruding slopey horn and follow the arcing seam up and right. (Cruxy!)  Work a slopey fold back to the left and top out, twice to reach the chains.  A short and stout route, as with most of the harder lines, this one is a bit of a puzzler.
content.location: To the left of Auchentoshen. Scramble up the hillside 25 feet or so to find a slanted edge that makes a nice shelf to tie in and change your shoes. For now, the belay stance is loose and rocky/dirt.
